bibl.title: Letter From [Henry Rose Carter] to L.L. Hidinger, November 22, 1921

div1.p: [Carter] refers to the coordination of malaria control with projects for agricultural drainage.

div1.head: Letter From [Henry Rose Carter] to L.L. Hidinger, November 22, 1921
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Drainage (agricultural)
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
November 22, 1921.
Mr. L. L. Hidinger, President,
Morgan Engineering Company,
Memphis, Tenn.
Dear Mr. Hidinger:
div1.p:
I was sick--ptomaine poisoning--last Wednesday and could not
properly debate your paper. I just want to express my gratifica-
tion--my very great gratification--at what promises to be the link-
ing up of malaria control with the projects for agricultural drain-
age. I have tried for this since 1917, but the war threw us back
for at least three years.

Naturally, in such projects one could not expect malaria con-
trol to be more than a side issue, and all that I asked or hoped for
was that this problem should be considered by the drainage engineer
in his planning for the direct object of his work--allowing it such
weight as its economic importance justified.

That malaria control in drainage districts is of economic im-
portance goes without saying--affecting the value, and hence the
selling price, of the lands--and this being recognized, how and to
what extent it is to be provided for, may be safely left to the
Engineering Company.
